722818f-b.title: Manhattan: Riverside Drive - 163rd Street
722818f-b.text:
(1)
Riverside Drive, north from and including 163rd Street,
In the centre is the New York Institution for the Deaf.
September 24, 1931.
P. L. Sperr.
(2)
The same, from a different angle.
May 23, 1929.
P. L. Sperr.
(3)
The same.
June 15, 1937.
P. L. Sperr.

722820f-a.title: Manhattan: Riverside Drive - 163rd Street
722820f-a.text:
Riverside Drive (thorough fare at the right upon which the
buildings shown,front), north from a point on a line with West
163rd Street (extreme right) showing a more or less general view of the
Washington Heights building outline on the westerly margin of Manhattan.
Two groups of structures of importance are:the low buildings of the
New York Institution for the Deaf (right, extending from West 163rd
to 165th Streets) and the Columbia University - Presbyterian Hospital
Medical Center which are just north of the aforementioned. View 2 of
this set, being from a vantage point to the north, emphasises the
latter. The foreground area is today (1938), included officially in
Port Washington Park, that marginal garden spot under the new George
Washington Bridge (in the left background).
September 24, 1931.
P. L. Sperr.

P. L. Sperr.

722819f-b.title: Manhattan: Riverside Drive - 163rd Street
722819f-b.text:
Riverside Drive, north from W. 163rd Street. Buildings shown
form the Columbia Medical Center. On the right are the main units
at Broadway. The Presbyterian Hospital School of Nursing is in the
center. To the left is the Neurological Institute.
View 3 is taken on that portion of the Drive, the Boulevard
Lafayette and includes at its right one of the old buildinrs that
formerly housed the New York Institution for the Deaf. This es-
carpment appeare in the midground of the preceding photos.
May 18, 1940
Views 1,2,3
P. L. Sperr

715719f-a.title: Manhattan: 163rd Street (West) - Riverside Drive
715719f-a.text:
West 163rd Street, north side, west from Riverside Drive,
showing the vacated grounds of the former New York School for
the Deaf extending to Fort Washington Avenue.
May 18, 1940
P. L. Sperr
Same as above, from another angle.
P. L. Sperr  April 27, 1941

722821f-a.title: Manhattan: Riverside Drive - 163rd Street
722821f-a.text:
Riverside Drive, at the N. E. corner of W. 163rd Street,
showing the grounds of the New York School for the Deaf. TRese
are being cleared of the former institution buildings; though
one still remains. In the background are the massive units of
the Columbia Medical Center.
View 1: August 21, 1939
Views 2,3: May 18, 1940
P. L. Sperr

722823f-c.title: Manhattan: Riverside Drive - 163rd Street
722823f-c.text:
(1)
Riverside Drive, east side, north from West 163rd to 165th
Streets, showing the buildings and grounds of the N.Y. Institution
for the Deaf.
June 15, 1937.
P. L. Sperr.
(2)
A limited view, showing only buildings at the N.E. corner of
West 163rd Street; the southwestern corner of these extensive grounds.
June 15, 1937.
P. L. Sperr.
(3)
A close up of building shown in No. 2.
June 15, 1937.
P. L. Sperr.
